title: Protocol to image and quantify nuclear pore complexes using high-resolution laser scanning confocal microscopy
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Part 1: Cell plating and culture
Timing: 16–24 h
      Part 1 of this protocol describes optimal seeding and culturing of cells
      to ensure proper distribution for clear imaging.
    
        Remove fibronectin from each well containing a Thermanox plastic
        coverslip (or ibidi optical polymer dish or chamber) using a p1000
        pipette or aspiration system.
      
        Plate an appropriate number of cells per coverslip to achieve 80–90%
        confluency at time of fixation. Add approximately 400–500 μL of culture
        media to each well, so that the cells are completely covered to prevent
        drying out.
      
Note: The number of cells needed to
      achieve the proper confluency is dependent upon cell line and length of
      cell culture
    
Critical: Make certain to plate cells
      at a density that will not cause overcrowding. Cells should be a monolayer
      at time of fixation.
    
        Place the plate in a 37°C 5% CO2 incubator and incubate 16–24
        h.
      
        The following morning, remove media and add approximately 500 μL of
        sterile 1× PBS to each well.
      
        Gently rinse the cells by running PBS over the coverslip to remove any
        dead or unattached cells.
      
Critical: Take care not to disturb
      attached cells.
    
        Remove PBS and add 500 μL of culture media. Continue to incubate cells
        until ready for fixation.
      
Note: If cells need to be treated, after
      PBS wash, add appropriate culture media with reagents. Continue to
      incubate cells in the incubator until intended length of cell treatment is
      concluded.
    
Part 2: Staining
Timing: 18–24 h
      Part 2 of this protocol describes the steps for fixing and staining cells
      and nuclei for nuclear pore quantification.
    
        Remove culture media from cells and wash with 1× PBS. Fix cells in
        ∼500 μL 4% paraformaldehyde for 20 min at 20–25°C.
      
Wash cells 3 times with 1× PBS.

Note: Fixation time can be optimized for
      each user with other cell types for best results.
    
Alternatives: Cells can be fixed
      in 100% methanol (MeOH) at −20°C for 10 min followed by washing 3 times
      with 1× PBS. However, it is recommended that fixations be optimized for
      each cell type and antibody since not all antibodies will work with MeOH.
    
Note: Cells can be store for several
      months in PBS at 4°C. However, for best results it is recommended they be
      stained within 4 weeks.
    
        Remove PBS from previously fixed cells and permeabilize with ∼500 μL of
        0.5% Triton-X 100 to completely cover the cells. Incubate for 10 min at
        20–25°C.
      
        Wash cells one time with 1× PBS and block by adding ∼500 μL blocking
        buffer. Incubate for 2 h at 20–25°C.
      
        While blocking, prepare primary antibody master mix.
        
            Dilute primary antibody in blocking buffer using manufacturers
            recommended dilution.
          
            Calculate a minimum of 400–500 μL per well. If using more than one
            primary antibody, dilute all antibodies in the same buffer solution
            to intended concentration.
          
Store at 4°C until ready to use.
        After 2 h, remove blocking buffer and add diluted primary antibody
        mixture to each well. Incubate at 4°C for 16–24 h.
      
Alternatives: Add ∼ 100 μL of
      diluted antibody to the coverslip and cover with a small piece of parafilm
      to prevent evaporation and drying.
    
Note: Mab414 (1:400 dilution) (Abcam,
      ab24609) is used in this example to stain nuclear pores. Many research
      papers have used monoclonal antibody (Mab414) for detection of nuclear
      pore complexes. This antibody recognizes the nucleoporins, Nup62, Nup153,
      and Nup358. Because the Mab414 antibody is commonly used in published
      studies, we have utilized it in this protocol. However, we have achieved
      acceptable confocal microscopy images also with a monoclonal Nup98
      antibody.

The following morning, remove primary antibody and wash cells in 1× PBS
        and rock for 5 min at 20–25°C. Repeat wash for a total of 3 times.
      
        While washing cells, dilute secondary antibody in 1× PBS according to
        manufacturer’s recommended dilution.
      
Note: If using more than one secondary
      antibody, dilute all antibodies in the same 1× PBS buffer solution as done
      in step 11.
    
        Remove third PBS wash and add 400–500 μL of secondary antibody solution
        to each well. Incubate the cells at 20–25°C in the dark for 2 h.
      
Alternatives: Add ∼ 100 μL of
      diluted antibody to the coverslip and cover with a small piece of parafilm
      to prevent evaporation and drying.
    
Critical: Be sure plate is stored in
      complete darkness, either in a drawer or covered with aluminum foil.
    
        After 2 h, remove secondary antibody and wash cells 3 times in 1× PBS
        for 5 min as in step 13.
      
        Dilute Hoechst in 1× PBS at approximately 1:500–1:1000 or optimize
        according to manufacturer’s recommendation.
        
incubate at 20–25°C in the dark for 5 min.
Wash briefly in 1× PBS.
        Using fine-tipped forceps, carefully remove coverslip from the well,
        taking care not to flip the coverslip or scratch cells from surface of
        the coverslip (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig1.jpg
              Figure 1. Prepare fixed cells for imaging
            
(A) Remove coverslip with fixed cells from a 24 well plate.
              (B) Coverslip with fixed cells facing up (red arrow) placed on
              microscope slide with spacers consisting of 2 strips of parafilm
              used to prevent cells from being flattened.
            
              (C) Add one drop of mounting media (red arrow) to the middle of
              the round coverslip containing fixed cells.
            
(D) Cover with a 22 mm × 22 mm glass coverslip #1.5.
              (E) Seal all four edges of the square coverslip with nail polish.

(F) Slide is completely sealed with nail polish and ready for
              imaging.
            
        Mount coverslip onto a precleaned microscope slide with cells facing up
        between two thin strips of pre-cut parafilm (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
      
Note: Slides may be cleaned with a Kimwipe
      and 100% Ethanol to remove dust or lint prior to mounting.
    
Note: The two parafilm strips act as
      spacers to avoid pressing cells and damaging cell morphology.
    
      The parafilm strips (approx. 2 mm × 15 mm) should be cut and placed on the
      microscope slide prior to placing coverslip to avoid drying out the cells.
      Take care to place the strips apart far enough to fit a 13 mm round
      coverslip, but still within the range of cover by the square coverslip
      (22 mm wide) that is to be mounted on top.
    
        Add 1 drop (approx. 25 μL) of mounting media and cover the cells with
        22 mm × 22 mm glass coverslip #1.5, allowing the media to cover the
        cells while avoiding bubbles (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C and 1D).
      
        Seal the edges of the glass coverslip with fingernail polish. Allow to
        dry before imaging. (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E and 1F).
      
Note: In the presented protocol, special
      consideration was given to the sample mounting (shown in
      Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). In the design/development of the sample
      mounting part of our protocol, we had to consider the following: (1)
      Optimal attachment of cardiomyocytes requires growth on plastic. To this
      end, we have seeded cardiomyocytes on round Thermanox coverslips. So as
      not to distort the light path with the plastic Thermanox coverslips, we
      have used cover glass for mounting (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). (2) In
      our experience, the use of spacers is necessary to limit the compression
      of nuclei by the coverslips being pulled by capillary forces (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). (3) For highest possible resolution, we have used an oil-immersion
      lens.

Part 3: Confocal microscopy
Timing: 45 - 60 m
    
      Part 3 of this protocol describes the procedure for imaging and
      quantifying nuclear pores using high resolution microscopy.
    
Note: This protocol utilizes Nikon
      equipment and software. Confocal microscopes from other manufacturers will
      enable the same experiments with minimal modifications of this protocol.
      We provide details of the hardware and terminology used, which should help
      identify corresponding equipment from other vendors.
    
        Whole cell imaging.
        
            Place slide containing mounted cells onto the stage of the confocal
            microscope. The slide should be placed so that the glass coverslip
            is facing toward the objective. (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig2.jpg
                  Figure 2. Cross-sectional diagram of sample mount
                
                  This protocol for heart muscle cells uses an inverted
                  microscope with a Nikon 100× Plan Apo, Lambda, oil 0.13 mm
                  working distance lens.
                
            Using the DAPI channel, locate cell nuclei under the 10× or 20×
            objective lens.
            
                Switch to the Plan Apo Lambda 100× oil immersion objective lens.
              
                Add 1 drop of Immersion Oil Type B to the surface of the lens.
              
                Identify cells with smooth nuclear border by bringing the edge
                of the nucleus into focus.
                
Critical: Only select
                  cells with smooth nuclear border in interphase where the
                  entire nuclear envelope can be seen as a disc. Cells
                  undergoing mitosis should be avoided due to the breakdown of
                  the nuclear envelope.
                
            Once a cell has been selected, set the pinhole size to 0.7AU.
            
                Set scanning format size to 1024 × 1024 pixel with a pixel dwell
                time of 1.1 μsec.
              
                Press the SCAN button to begin scanning.
                table:files/protocols_protocol_2950_7.csv
Note: See Image Acquisition
                  Parameters (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]) for suggested
                  settings.
                
            Adjust the laser power and gain at the optimal focal plane for each
            subcellular structure (nucleus, nuclear pores, etc). Modify the
            focus as needed.
            
Critical: Avoid oversaturation
              (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).

Note: Laser power and gain
              settings for each channel may vary on different systems and with
              individual users. The overall principal is to avoid over
              oversaturation.
            
Note: Because it is important to
              use the full dynamic range of the detector, it is recommended to
              evaluate the Look Up Table (LUT) histogram for appropriate display
              of low through high range of intensity (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
            
            Take an image of the cell of interest by selecting
            CAPTURE. The captured image will appear with all fluorophores
            overlayed. Save both the ND file, the captured raw data containing
            separate channel images for each fluorophore, and a TIFF file
            representing all fluorophores (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig3.jpg
                  Figure 3. Neonatal rat cardiomyocyte imaged on high resolution
                  with a Plan Apo Lambda 100× oil lens objective using Nikon A1R
                  scanning laser confocal microscope
                
Scale bar 10 μm.
Note: Terminology or directions
              for collecting images may vary on different systems.
            
        Nucleus and Nuclear Pore Imaging.
        
            Select SCAN again and crop the image so the nucleus engulfs
            the entire scanning field while leaving room to visualize the entire
            nuclear envelope and surrounding nuclear pores (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]
            and 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig4.jpg
                  Figure 4. Examples of oversaturation
                
                  (A) Oversaturated single plane photomicrograph of nuclear
                  pores. Look Up Table (LUT) histogram showing saturation
                  exceeding 80–90% of pixel gray value. Scale bar 2 μm.
                
                  (B) Appropriately saturated single plane photomicrograph of
                  nuclear pores. Look Up Table (LUT) histogram showing
                  saturation within 80–90% of pixel gray value. Scale bar 2 μm.
                
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig5.jpg
                  Figure 5. Acquiring Z-stack image Next step of appropriately
                  saturated nucleus in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B
                
                  (A) Screen shot of the ND Acquisition window to
                  demonstrate setting z-stack parameters.
                
                  (B) Z-stack ND file image of neonatal rat cardiomyocyte
                  acquired using Plan Apo Lambda 100× oil 1.45NA, 0.133 mm lens
                  objective. Scale bar 2 μm.

(C) 2D Max projection image of scanned nucleus showing merged
                  image along with separate channels. Scale bar 2 μm.
                
                  (D) Look Up Table (LUT) indicating appropriate saturation
                  levels.
                
Note: Use the crop function rather
              than optical zoom to avoid changing the pixel size
            
            Adjust the pinhole size to 0.4 AU to decrease the amount of
            scattered light and increase the resolution to enhance the
            definition of the nuclear pores.
            
                Set the scanning format size to 2048 × 2048 pixel with a
                pixel dwell time of 3.2 μsec.
                
Note: See Image Acquisition
                  Parameters (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]) for suggested
                  settings.
                
Note: After decreasing the
                  pinhole size, re-adjust the laser power and gain as needed for
                  each laser to increase the brightness of the subcellular
                  structures. Once the changes have been made, maintain the
                  parameters for all similar acquisitions.
                
Critical: Avoid
                  oversaturation (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
                
            Once the pinhole has been adjusted to 0.4AU and the laser power and
            gain have been established, obtain a 3D image using the Z-series
            Acquisition on Nikon Elements software.
            
                Select the Acquisition tab and click the
                Z-stack box.
              
                Set the Z range by setting the top and bottom positions of the
                nucleus.
              
                Focus on the top of the nucleus and press the Top button.
              
                Move the focus to the bottom of the nucleus and press the
                Bottom button.
              
                Set the Z-step size to 0.3 μm to cover the entire depth of the
                nucleus.
              
                Select Run Now. Save image as an ND file. (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5])
                
Note: Terminology or
                  directions for collecting images may vary on different
                  systems.
                
Note: In this protocol, we
                  have used a z-step size of 0.3.μm. Using the formula for
                  z-axis resolution of a confocal light path :
                  
 r z 
=
 1.4 n λ 
 N A  2
                  for determining the optical resolution limit in z-axis, we

calculated that the combined refractive index of cover glass
                  and glycerol-based mounting medium of approximately 1.45, an
                  emission peak wavelength of 525 nm for Alexa 488, and a
                  numerical aperture (NA) of the objective lens of 1.45 yields a
                  z-axis resolution of 507 nm. As such, this protocol
                  oversamples in z-axis. Users who are interested in reducing
                  microscope time for acquisition could use a wider step size in
                  z-axis as appropriate for their equipment.
                
        3D data analysis using Nikon Elements software.
        
Note: This protocol uses Nikon
          Elements software to quantify nuclear pore complexes. However, several
          open-source software options are available which can be used. Steps
          using Fiji (ImageJ) are outlined in Step 25.
        
            Define Binary Threshold.
            
                Convert 3D Z-stack ND file to a Max (maximum) Intensity
                Projection image (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A and 6B).
                
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig6.jpg
                      Figure 6. Obtain max projection and define binary
                    
                      (A) Z-stack image of nucleus. Red arrow indicates tab used
                      to obtain a max projection image Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
(B) Max projection image of nucleus. Scale bar 2 μm.
                      (C) Max projection image of nucleus. Red arrow indicates
                      drop down box used to “create new document” to define
                      binary threshold. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (D) New document used to define threshold Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (E) Select DAPI Channel under New Document used to define
                      binary.
                    
                      (F) Screen shot of the dialogue box for defining binary
                      threshold parameters.
                    
                      (G–I) (G) Select area of contrast to define binary (H)
                      Thresholding after binary threshold is defined (I) Final
                      Threshold after additional parameters are adjusted,
                      including Smooth, Clean, Fill holes, Separate.
                    
                Right click in the Max Intensity Projection image and select
                New Document (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C and 6D).
              
                Using the New Document image (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]D), obtain binary threshold under the DAPI channel. Click

within the nucleus in several areas. Be sure to select both
                light and dark regions (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]E and 6G).
              
                Define parameters in thresholding dialogue box to determine
                binary (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]F,6H, and 6I).
              
            Convert Binary to ROI.
            
                Select the ROI tab located on the tool bar above the
                image (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A).
                
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig7.jpg
                      Figure 7. Convert Binary to ROI
                    
                      (A) Image of final binary threshold. Red arrow indicates
                      the dropdown box used to Move binary to ROI.
                    
                      (B) Image of binary converted to ROI. Red arrow indicates
                      selection of ROI in dropdown box.
                    
                      (C) Original Z-stack image. Red arrow indicates the
                      dropdown box used to Paste ROI from thresholding.
                    
                      (D) Original Z-stack image showing ROI which will be used
                      for nuclear pore quantification. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                Select Move Binary to ROI (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A).
              
                Right click within the ROI. Select Copy ROI (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B).
              
                Paste ROI into the ORIGINAL Z-Stack image (Figures 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]C and 7D).
                
Critical: Do not paste ROI
                  in Max Intensity Projection image. Max Intensity Projection
                  image will not allow for scrolling through the optical
                  sections taken in the Z-stack in step 23c.
                
            Select proper Z-stack optical sections for quantification.
            
                In the Z-Stack image, choose the top and bottom sections of the
                nucleus showing pores on the surface and along the edge of the
                nuclear envelope (NE) (Figures 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A and 9B).
                
Critical: Do not select
                  optical sections that show only the edge of the NE or those
                  that exclude the edge of the NE (Figures 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A and 8B).
                
                Under the Binary tab located on the tool bar, select
                Spot Detection -> Bright Spots ->
                Bright and Clustered (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]C).
                
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig8.jpg
                      Figure 8. Identify correct Z-stack optical sections for
                      counting nuclear pores
                    
                      (A) Optical section in Z-stack showing nuclear pores only

on the surface of the nuclear envelope. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (B) Optical section in Z-stack showing nuclear pores only
                      along the edge of the nuclear envelope. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (C) Optical section in Z-stack showing nuclear pores along
                      the edge and surface of the nuclear envelope. Scale bar
                      2 μm.
                    
                Select the channel used to stain the pores and set parameters to
                identify nuclear pores. (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]E).
                
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig9.jpg
                      Figure 9. Identify nuclear pores stained with Mab414 using
                      spot detection with Nikon Elements Software
                    
                      (A) Lowest optical section in Z-stack, indicated by red
                      arrow, used for counting nuclear pores along the edge and
                      surface of the nuclear envelope. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (B) Highest optical section in Z-stack, indicated by red
                      arrow, used for counting nuclear pores along the edge and
                      surface of the nuclear envelope. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (C) Original z-stack image. Red arrows indicate
                      spot detection and bright spots located
                      under the Binary tab. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (D) Nuclear pores detected by spot detection prior to
                      parameters adjustment. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (E) Zoomed-in screen shot of Spot Detection box
                      used to set parameters for selecting nuclear pores to be
                      counted.
                    
1px.
Diameter 0.19 μm.
Contrast ∼17.
Object symmetry = all.
Check Remove dark objects.
Check Apply to all frames.
Check Preview.
                Select either the top or bottom section of the nucleus to begin
                the quantification. (Figures 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A and 9B).
              
                Adjust remove dark objects in the
                spot detection dialogue box iteratively until there is an
                appropriate optimum of included and excluded objects (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]E).
              
            Quantification of Nuclear Pores.
            
                Once the parameters have been defined in the spot detection
                dialogue box, hit OK (Figures 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]D and
                9E).
              
                Open Automated Measurement Result under the
                Analysis tab in the tool bar.

Select ROI DATA in the first drop down box, indicated by a
                yellow arrow in Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]C.
                
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig10.jpg
                      Figure 10. Quantification of nuclear pores stained with
                      Mab414
                    
                      (A) Nuclear pore quantification on the lowest optical
                      section in the Z-stack showing pores along the edge and
                      surface of the nuclear envelope. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (B) Nuclear pore quantification on the highest optical
                      section in the Z-stack showing pores along the edge and
                      surface of the nuclear envelope. Scale bar 2 μm.
                    
                      (C) Screen shot image of
                      Automated Measurement Results dialogue box. Yellow
                      arrow indicates “ROI Data” drop down box; white arrow,
                      “ROI Area” drop down box; red arrows, Number of Objects
                      (nuclear pore count), ROI Area, and refresh button used to
                      obtain counts from both sections.
                    
                Select ROI AREA in the second drop down box, indicated by a
                white arrow in Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]C.
              
                Hit the refresh button, indicated by the top red arrow in
                Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]C. This will give the number of
                nuclear pores along with the ROI area for that section.
              
                Export data to Excel. Data will include the number of pores as
                well as the ROI area.
              
                Without changing any settings, scroll down to the other optical
                section (top or bottom) and hit the refresh button again (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]C). The number of pores will be updated.
              
Export data.
                To calculate the total number of pores for the nucleus, add the
                two numbers. For area density, divide the total number of pores
                by the area of the ROI (nucleus) (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]C).
              
        3D data analysis using Fiji (image J).
        
Note: Here we outline steps to
          quantify nuclear pores using Fiji (Image J) with and without the
          utilization of Gaussian Blur to reduce image noise:
        
            Quantification steps using Gaussian Blur (Figures 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]A–11E):
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2950-Fig11.jpg

Figure 11. Quantification of nuclear pores stained with Mab414
                  using Fiji/ImageJ
                
                  (A–I) Workflow for quantification with (A–E) and without (F–I)
                  Gaussian blurring. (A) DNA staining with Hoechst to delineate
                  the boundaries of the nucleus. (B) Use of Gaussian Blur on
                  photomicrograph of nuclear pores stained with Mab414 with
                  sigma radius of 1 (left panel) and 2 (right panel). (C)
                  Difference of Gaussians (DoG): Subtraction of photomicrograph
                  2 (sigma 2) from photomicrograph 1 (sigma 1). (D) Thresholding
                  and binary on nuclear pore complex image. (E) Digital
                  quantification yields nuclear pore count of 261. (F) DNA
                  staining with Hoechst to delineate the boundaries of the
                  nucleus. (G) Photomicrograph of nuclear pores stained with
                  Mab414. (H) Thresholding and binary on nuclear pore complex
                  image. (I) Digital quantification yields nuclear pore count of
                  369.
                
Load raw data file into ImageJ.
                Create 2 duplicates of the of the original file for the channel
                used to detect nuclear pores and name as 1 and 2.
              
                Threshold on the DAPI channel to create an ROI of the nucleus.
              
Create ROI: Edit -> selection ->create selection.
Copy ROI to both duplicates.
                Create a Gaussian Blur on each of the duplicates. Process
                ->Filter -> Gaussian Blur.
              
                For Image 2 use a Sigma (radius) of 2. For Image 1 use a Sigma
                (radius) of 1.
              
                Find the Difference of Gaussians (DoG) by subtracting image 2
                from image 1.
              
Process -> Image Calculator.
Choose “1” as image 1 and “2” as image 2.
Operation = subtract.
Create new window.
Adjust brightness and contrast.
Threshold the nuclear pores on the DoG image.
Separate particles: Process -> Binary ->Watershed.
                If needed, remove errant particles. Process -> Binary ->
                Open.
              
                Set size measurements. Analyze ->Set measurement.
                Check Limit Threshold box.
                Check Bounding rectangle box to count particles within the ROI
                only.
              
Count Pores.

Analyze ->Analyze particles.
                Set size parameters and additional outputs needed.
                Hit OK. Summary will show total number as well as other overall
                measurements.
              
            Quantification Steps without the use of Gaussian Blur (Figures 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]F–11I):
            
Load raw data file into image J.
                Threshold on the DAPI channel to create an ROI of the nucleus.
              
Binary -> open.
Edit -> selection -> create selection for ROI.
Copy ROI.
Adjust brightness and contrast.
Threshold the nuclear pores.
Separate particles: Process -> Binary -> Watershed.
Set size measurement: Analyze -> Set measurement.
Check Limit Threshold box.
                Check Bounding rectangle box to count particles within the ROI
                only.
              
Count pores.
                Analyze -> Analyze particles.
                Set size parameters and additional outputs needed.
                Hit ok. Summary will show total number as well as other overall
                measurements.
